name: Mollie Brinker
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
I run cross country and track where head injuries almost never occur, so looking at this graph was a little bit disturbing. I could never imagine playing a sport that involved a huge chance of being severely hurt. If I had kids, I would never want them doing a sport where high risk of injury was a part of the game. Damage to someone’s brain is nothing to take lightly, and football is the number one contender, by far. 

Ankle, knee and hand injuries also occur in football players much more than any other sport. But truly, these seem insignificant compared to irreversible head injuries. Your hand can heal and your ankle can get wrapped in a cast, but you only get one brain and its healing process is very different than other body parts. 

I hope football players and coaches start to realize the danger and long term effects of damaging teen’s bodies like that.

Our coaches do that, but we did have some concussions. That just comes with playing the sport.

I run cross country and track where head injuries almost never occur, so looking at this graph was a little bit disturbing. I could never imagine playing a sport that involved a huge chance of being severely hurt. If I had kids, I would never want them doing a sport where high risk of injury was a part of the game. Damage to someone’s brain is nothing to take lightly, and football is the number one contender, by far. 

Ankle, knee and hand injuries also occur in football players much more than any other sport. But truly, these seem insignificant compared to irreversible head injuries. Your hand can heal and your ankle can get wrapped in a cast, but you only get one brain and its healing process is very different than other body parts. 

I hope football players and coaches start to realize the danger and long term effects of damaging teen’s bodies like that.

name: Shubh Khanna
comment info: The infographic illustrates the variation in the injuries students sustain across different sports. The author used different sized circles overlayed on top of specific body areas to highlight the number of specific injuries for a particular sport in a sample of 10,000 students. We can conclude from the infographic that football is associated with more frequent injuries, especially head, hand, knee, and angle injuries. These results are not surprising – football is contact-heavy, and involves collission of heads, pushing, and quick changes of directions, all which correspond to higher rates of injuries. While the results make sense, I am extremely curious on how the 10,000 samples were collected. The region and district in which a student plays is extremely important because different areas have different regulations on contact and perhaps normalize certain forms of contact that other regions do not. Furthermore, blocking between experienced athletes and new athletes would be effective in order to see if there are any differences between the two groups, as new athletes are likely less fit and have higher risks of becoming injured. Regardless, the infographic and study conducted are important in understanding the relationship between high school sports and injuries – it can be used in helping guide parents in what sports their child should play, and in regulating policies of specific sports. I would title it "When Recreation Becomes Injurious."

name: Madelyn Myers
comment info:
Serious Consequences for a Fun Game 
Football is without a doubt the most popular high school sport. It’s the focus of countless movies, it can get students scholarships, and for a select few, it could become a career. But let’s back up a little, because very few high school football players will ever go pro, and think about what the cost is of playing a contact sport. Every athlete will get injured at some point, it’s a part of the sport. But just because injuries are common, and expected doesn’t mean they aren’t causing some serious damage. 

I noticed that head injuries in football are almost double in any other sport, but with it being America’s most popular sport I wonder why there aren’t more people working to make it safer for those playing it.The short term effects of a concussion are bad enough for high school students, who are too busy to be basically useless for a week or two at school while they’re recovering. That time can set you back! But from what we know, too many head injuries can cause serious effects later in life. Playing football in high school shouldn't mean they should be punished with early memory loss!

name: Keira McWilliams
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington NC
comment info:
The Wellbeing of Student Athletes
I am a student athlete. I run cross country and track year round, which may not seem like a high impact sport, but it produces many injuries. I know this because I had a stress fracture for almost a year and many of my teammates, both male and female, struggle with the frustration and pain of injuries as well. From my experience, I wonder about the psychological effect on students from being sidelined during their injury and how it varies by sport. I also wonder how the injuries within sports occur. In sports such as football and hockey that are known for high physical impact, it is heavily implied that injuries are caused by the impact. In other sports such as soccer or basketball where there is less contact, I begin to question if the injuries are from overuse (which is what my personal injury was from) or from the contact within the sport. By questioning this, I began to notice how common injuries are for athletes, despite the use of protection such as helmets, shin guards, etc. If injuries are both physically and psychologically taxing for students, who are still adolescents, we should be making sure we are taking all preventative measures possible to ensure that minimal student injuries occur.

However, I could never imagine playing a sport and getting seriously hurt, and still wanting to play.

name: Ella Shynett
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Headline: Trauma Galore
This graph was very interesting to see. We're already aware of the risk of injury from sports, whether it's through the TV at home or it possibly happening to yourself. But to see it all collected in a data set makes you realize the gravity of these injuries and the possible long term effects it could have on a player.

While it is still the second highest, I noticed that the head trauma for hockey was significantly lower than football. Growing up hearing stories from my mother about how her brothers used to end up in violent fights after an assumed foul while playing hockey that usually resulted in a staple to head, it was somewhat jarring to see the difference between football and hockey. Perhaps this is the results of new rules being placed in recent years?

Seeing the vast amount of trauma within the ankle as the result of playing football really made me wonder how sports that majorly focus on using the feet like soccer don't have as many injuries. Possibly this is because of the way the balls within the game are handled? I'm not very well-versed in the world of sports so I don't really understand.

name: Sean Hession
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Headline: Why so many injuries?
   There are far too many injuries during high school men's sports, especially head injuries. This is what I noticed while observing a graph about how often high school sports players are injured while playing a sport. As a high school lacrosse player, I am appalled by the number of total injuries that occurred. During just 10,000 competition plays, 37 marked injuries took place. I was shocked that there were this many. Even though I know that the sport is very contact-focused, I did not expect a number that high. This number, while it is shocking, is only fourth-highest among popular sports, and it pales in comparison to the number that occur in football. Football causes 34 head injuries every 10,000 plays. That is almost the total number of all that occurred during lacrosse, and that number is only referring to head injuries. In addition, this number only encompasses competition plays, when practice time is much more common than competition and provides even more opportunities for injury. These games need to be safer.
    With this in mind, I wonder what the effect of safer game rules and better equipment would be on the amount of injuries in these sports. If there were better padding in sports with too many injuries, such as football, perhaps there would be less bodily harm. Better helmets could lower the amount of head injuries, and perhaps new rules could make the game less violent in order to make high school sports safer for the youth.

name: Daniel Guy

Ever since middle school I have noticed that football has the most injuries overall, despite that football is still one of the top sports in America and is enjoyed by the viewers and the players. When I was younger I wanted to play football but my parents always said no, I never understood that until now. They were concerned for my well being and scared that the injuries would have an affect on my school work and my life and looking back now I understand their worries. I have a number of friends who have played football  and have gotten injuries from knee injuries all the way to a severe concussions. Injuries to the head cause a number of problems such as having issues focusing in school and  in life in general which will affect their future selves and how they can provide for their families. Through all of the effort in making football a safer sport there are still too many injuries. I wonder what the NFL’s next step towards safety in football will be.

name: Mackenzie Wernicke
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Headline: Hungry to Win, How Hungry is Too Hungry?
From this graph I notice that there are many risks associated with playing any sport, especially as a boy, due to their competitive and aggressive nature. Football is most commonly known for its head injuries, the debates on how to make it safer are plentiful. Constant arguing over whether or not to change the rules, the equipment, or even the entire sport to make it safer for kids. Something that needs to be pointed out is that there is risk associated with everything sport you play, it just depends on how comfortable you are with taking those risks. After looking at this graph, I wonder what keeps these boys interested in these sports if there is such a high risk of injury. I guess it could be their high adrenaline levels, their aggressive nature as stated before, or just their hunger to the best. But where is the line between risk and reward? All Injuries add up over time and take a large toll on your body? As an athlete, I’m not against playing sports and getting hurt, it builds character and helps us develop into stronger people, but it’s the ones who push themselves past their threshold that I'm worried about. Sports are good for your health, mentally and physically, for the most part, it’s one of the best ways to release your anger and frustration, and it keeps you in shape but you need to understand when you've overworked yourself.

I was surprised however when I saw that wrestling was listed above lacrosse for certain injuries such as head and arms. I play basketball and through that I have had a concussion and a dislocated finger. Sitting out was no fun and when I was playing again I still felt like I was gonna get hurt again.  When I watch friends of mine that play these sports come away with major or minor injuries it makes me wonder how and when things will change so the players feel more protected and can play aggressively but safe. Myself, like any other sports lover, want to watch a good game that is lively and competitive. However, it becomes unbearable to watch when players have to be carted off the fields or courts. As sports takes a front seat in more people's lives, it's an important  job to take care of our athletes.

Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s infographic shows the common injuries for high school boys by sport.  The statistics are the number of injuries per 10,000 competition plays.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the main ideas about the graph.

name: Mr. Eggo
comment info:
We notice that: 
- Football seems to be the most dangerous sport for injuries, as it has the highest total number of injuries, and leads the pack in most areas. 
- The head is the most frequently injured area. 
- Most injuries occur around the joints, and not on the long bones. 

We wonder: 
- What "counts" as an injury? A hospitalization? Missing a game? Or just 'walking it off'?
- Are these students trained on injury prevention? And if not, what would these graphs look like if they were? 
- Is there a reason why only these categories are presented? Or is this all the categories of injured area that there are? E.g. is there some data about foot injuries that are not included? If so, is that because it is only represented in one of the sports, or is it perhaps because it occurs with low frequency? 

Our title is: 
Injuries in high school boys: "Sports hurt, Sports scar, Sports wound and mark".https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=soDZBW-1P04
